Ruby Bridges to speak and sign books at BYU. The first African-American to ever attend a desegregated school will speak at BYU on Nov. 19. Ruby Bridges started at the New Orleans school as a first grade student and appears Norman Rockwell's painting, "The Problem We all Live With." The young girl was invited to attend the school due to her high test scores. Protesters yelled at Bridges as she entered the school according to the BYU Museum of Art.
Bridges' lecture will take place in conjunction with the Nov. 20 opening of the Norman Rockwell Exhibit which will run through Feb 13. Following her address, Bridges will sign her books "Through My Eyes" and "Ruby Bridges Goes to School" in addition to Robert Coles' "The Story of Ruby Bridges". These books will be for sale in the Museum of Art store. Bridges will speak in the BYU Museum of Art. Doors will open at 6 p.m. This event is free and open to the public. Tickets are not required.
